author: void.xyz
content: I have a noob question about the functionality of Geth. How does a completely new node (that is, not initially knowing any other nodes on the network) know the IP address of the first node to connect to?

author: sky.cactus
content: Go-ethereum is shipped with a configuration that includes "bootstrap nodes".  These are the initial nodes you connect to to get peers from.  You can change them or add more if you don't trust the built-in bootstrap nodes.

author: sandreckoner
content:
I have a noobie question.. I know bitcoin has an algorithm that even transactions that didn't pay any fees are eventually included in a block. The longer you wait, the higher the priority for your tx.
Does ethereum have anything similar? If I send a simple approve/unapprove tx with 1 gwei, will it eventually be included in a block even if the gas doesn't actually drop to 1?

author: pietjepuk
content: Nope. Only transactions that have a maxFeePerGas >= baseFeePerGas can be included. Oversimplifying a little, there's less chance overpaying with EIP-1559 but also less chance of getting a lowball offer in.

author: treyzania
content: This is completely out of a miner's own altruism though, the game-theoretically optimal tx inclusion strategy does not do this

author: jacknelson
content: Hey I was writing a quick little key generator for a bip39 key and I know you can use crypto.getRandomValues but does anyone else have any better suggestions?
